The bread was the best part but I don't think it is worth a repeat trip. With all the pizza places in Chicago, this one definately falls amongst the bottom half.

I thought everything was over-hyped but the bread.  The bread was very seasoned, almost too salty.  The pizza pot pie was just alright, but not the mind blowing experience I was led to belive.  I mean its sausage, pizza sause, and chese thrown in a pie made of pizza dough.  The grinders that the table next too us looked pretty good.  If I get convinced to go back, that's what I'll have. Service is good, I went on a weeknight so it was busy but not packed.  Maybe I should give it 3 stars, but I'm a hater and I think its over rated.    Peace.

(Actually 4.5 stars) Only reasons it's not 5 stars are: (1) cash only (annoying...sometimes i am craving CPOG and I haven't been paid yet and I need to use the Visa...) (2) long wait and the guy who "takes your name" actually doesn't write it down and there have been a couple times that 2-tops who came in after us (we were also a 2-top) were seated before us.....and it didn't seem like they were VIP or relatives of this guy or whatever.  So that was annoying.   The delicious flat bread, salad, salad dressing and pizza pies/puffs make me quickly get over that incident listed under (2) and continue coming back!

Edit: Ok, this is one of those places that requires your entire party to be there.....because they are always busy. Whatever. This place is always good, the food is ridiculously consistent. Just understand that its cooked 100% by people that are not Italian in any way. But it is good, and the servers do their job. It just works ---------------------- My original review: Not sure why Chicagoans really love this place. When I arrived, I told the host that we were ready to be seated (we wanted drinks and an app), the following happened: Me: Hi there, we need a table for four. Host: OK, let me know when your entire party is here. Me: Well, they might be a while, but we are ready. Host: OK, let me know when they arrive. Me: (ugly look) Then when we got the food, it was OK - but nothing out of this world or anything. I had just gotten out of the hospital after surgery, so that may have had a factor in the low rating. However, if I end up at this place again and have a better experience, I will edit this post.

The Oven Grinder, one of my favorite restaurants to take friends from out of town, is responsible for a certain monomania of mine--you guessed it, the super-fantastic pizza pot pie.  What--never heard of it?  Sounds like it's time for somebody's taste buds to step out and start living.    Yes, there are some other choices on the menu, sandwiches and salads and so forth, but as far as I'm concerned, the Oven Grinder is essentially a one-trick pony.  But  what a doozy of a trick!  And with warmth and ever a packed, salivating house to enjoy it in, you've got nothing stopping you, lest it be a legitimate fear of contracting a case of pizza-pot-pie fever.

all I can say is Eh. The grinders are eh. and the 'amazing' pizza pot pie thing is eh. The grinder had pretty decent salami and was toasted.  The bread wasn't anything to rave about. On to the pizza.  Cut up my damn mushroom for the pizza.  I don't want one freakin huge white button shroom taking up the majority of my toppings (or should I say filling until they flip it out?? The Mediterranean bread was pretty good though.  I don't think anything is that memorable or worth coming back to
3.5 Stars I enjoyed my meal and felt that the service was adequate.  I felt the quality of the pizza was a disappointment based on the stellar reviews on metromix and yelp.

I've been thinking about this place for over a decade. Back in 1997, I was living in Lincoln Park, not far from this place. I took my -then- girlfriend for a romantic night out. What a great spot. I loved that it was a lookout for the St. Valentine's Day Massacre, though that's a bit weird.  The pizza was excellent. It's really unique. If I remember correctly, they serve it upside down. Anyway, it's a must try.

Maybe my experience is marred by the fact my ex took me here. Maybe it is because the food really does suck. I remember it being so unimpressive that I want to ask everyone that asks me over enthusiastically for directions to this place if they get free crack with their meal....'cuz I think they forgot mine.

OK.  This place is just awesome.  There is no other word to describe it.  The pizza is great and the service is fantastic.  We were there one evening while it was snowing and had a table by the window.  With all the Christmas lights on and the wood paneling, I felt like I was in some ski lodge in Aspen rather than on Clark St.  All I needed was a roaring fireplace.   A glass of wine is a FULL glass, which was awesome.  You never get that very often anymore.   And to all the haters out there, you all are just sore because there is a "way" and a "system" about this place that you either didnt know about or chose to ignore, such as: The mushrooms are a cool feature- where else do you get a whole mushroom rammed inside a pizza?  If it is so upsetting to you, you CAN order it WITHOUT them!  Whoa, what a concept!  BTW, the way these pies are made is GENIUS and why noone has copied them by now is mind-boggling.  The crust is flawlessly baked and soft, and everything just falls into place perfectly once removed from the bowl.  Can you also say boo-yeah to a rockin meat sauce?  Its almost better than homemade! The interior rocks, it is Old School Chicago and probably hasnt been touched since it opened in '72.  Yes, it could be bigger, but whatever.  Just dont go at 7:30pm on a Saturday when it's at its craziest and you can get in and be served in no time.  There.  Problem solved.   Dont come in all prima-donna and peeved that they only take cash or its first-come-first-served basis.  Again, too bad.  If its that tragic you can order take out from Domino's.   Its these little idiosyncracies that make this place excellent and a real treat.  Pies can also be purchased frozen to go.

Really?  This is what everyone's all amped up about? The Good: The mediterranean bread covered in loads of herbs and spices is delicious.  I could eat it all day.  The pizza pot pie was good, but nothing amazing.  The sauce was the only thing that made it anything better than average. The Bad: What's with the huge raw mushrooms in the middle of the pizza?  I'm sure I'm not the only one who expects mushrooms on pizza to be cooked in some way, shape, or form.  If the pizza baking process is going to leave them raw, then please saute or bake those effing tubers prior to putting them in my pizza pot thingee!  Please. The Ugly: There is nothing truly horrendous about the food besides maybe the prices.  The bread at $6 a serving (it's just bread!) and the individual pizzas at $10 a pop seem a little inflated.  But I could live with that if it weren't for the truly terrible abominations in this restaurant.   The layout of CPOG is miserable. It's a maze of bulky wooden booths. The dining room is extremely cramped and it's difficult to get anywhere once you're past the host stand.  If people are going separate ways down an aisle, one of them has to make an extreme concession to let the other pass.  Pre-Subway Jared, would not have been able to get to any of their tables. Absurdly, they don't take credit cards.  This is appalling to me.  I understand if you have a small family joint, or traffic in low price items, but the place has a consistent line out the door and what I would imagine is an average per person bill in the range of $15-$20.  I think CPOG can afford the few credit card percentage points, especially for what they are charging for freaking bread. Even more absurdly, they charge for pop refills.  For full disclosure, I am a complete diet soda junky.  When dining at a restaurant, I will consume several glasses at a minimum.  I know it's not a good thing, but it's who I am.  Now, fountain soda pop is almost universally the highest margin item in the restaurant industry.  It literally costs them pennies per serving.  This is why all decent human beings give you free refills when you pay around 2 bucks for a glass.  The folks behind CPOG are not said decent people.  They are dirty rotten money grubbing a-holes.  They give you a tiny glass to begin with (maybe 10 oz.), load it up with ice, and then charge you $1.75 every time you get a  refill.  Our waitress never bothered to inform me of this.  When I brought this to her attention upon receiving the bill, she said "Oh, I'm sorry, I usually tell everyone." Like I said, the food is okay, but I cannot get over the myriad of issues I have with this place.  Given just one or two, I would be able to stomach it, but combining them all, I can't say I'll be back to CPOG unless it's against my will.  Why anyone would wait large stretches of time (as folks apparently so often do here) is beyond me.

Despite its name, the real key here is its huge, delicious salads.  The Great American is my personal favorite, and their poppy seed and creamy garlic dressings are incredibly good (mixing them is even better).  Start with the Mediterranean bread (white is better than wheat) and then split a salad (small feeds at least two, large at least four).  If you're there with a bunch of people, then go for the pizza or a grinder.  Both are good, but not what you'll remember.  Cash only.
Pizza pot pie is their take on the deep dish. Near the ballpark, fans have been known to storm this place so beware of game day. The family style food will keep you warm on a cold day.

This is by far one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago.  It's so unique in so many ways.  Even though at times you are forced to wait 1-2 hours to get seated, the wait is well worth it for the amazing food! I love how the owner/host doesn't take down names and he is just able to remember the order of the people waiting.  He is so friendly and always pleasant whenever I come.  And he gave me a free meditteranean bread because I was raving about it to my friends.   While you wait you can order a glass of wine and stand or sit at the bar.  The glasses of wine are not your typical 5 oz pours like other hoity toity restaurants in the city where you pay $10-12.  These are filled to the top buckets of wine for right around $7.  Amazing! Once you get a seat, you must order the meditteranean bread.  It's a freshly made piece of flat bread with a special blend of spices.  So delicious.  I would also recommend ordering a salad and they are served with their 2 homeade dressing that you mix together for a completely different and unique flavor.  I've never ordered anything but the pizza pot pies and I probably never will.  You get 4 choices when ordering these....1/2 lb or 1 lb, wheat or white, vegetarian or meat sauce, mushrooms or no mushrooms.  That's all, plain and simple, but yet so great!  They are brought out and they look somewhat like a mushroom on the tray and then the server scoops out the pie and flips it over to reveal melted cheese and saucy goodness.  **They are very careful if you are a vegetarian to make sure that the spoon used to scoop out the pies does not go into a meat sauce first and then a veggie one, as to not cross contaminate.  If they do make that mistake, they will make you a new one, no questions asked.   I have taken many friends and family members to this place and they have all been impressed!  You definitely need to go and try it!

So I'm flipping channels the other week and I came across a special on the Best Pizza in America (I think it was on the Travel channel?)--and they mentioned that Chicago Pizza and Oven Grinder had these great, unique "pizza pot pies." How could I resist that? I planned a trip for the next weekend. I definitely recommend going between the lunch and dinner rush hours if you're going on a Saturday--we showed up about 3:30 and only had to wait about 30 minutes (everyone after us was told 45). The host (who I assume may have also been the owner) never took anyone's name, but remembered every party in order. Like clockwork, when our wait was up, he came and brought us to our table. The atmosphere is so unique--it's decorated like a German ski lodge with tons of logs and wooden booths, etc. We (my sister and I) got the Mediterranean Bread to start: a huge disk of dough--comes in either white or whole wheat, we chose wheat--covered in all sorts of herbs. It's their most popular menu item, and I can definitely see why! Next, we split a half-pounder Pizza Pot Pie (sans mushrooms--and which also comes in white or wheat, we got white this time b/c the server said the wheat crust is noticeably thicker): The cheese and sauce (which was a rich, meaty sauce--absolutely made my day!) are baked in a dish separately from the crust, which is essentially a big pizza crust bread bowl. The crust is placed on top of the dish like a mushroom cap and then inverted. The server spoons the cheese/sauce into the bread bowl and also cut it in half for us. Seriously--some of the best pizza EVER (and I'm extremely picky when it comes to pizza). The flavor is amazing and I love (LOVE) the meat sauce! My sister and I were both stuffed at the end, but were able to finish everything so we didn't have to cart leftovers around town. Each of us got a soda too, and our total bill was only 23 dollars and change--worth every penny.

The pizza pot pie is an original idea, which turned out to be a fantastic treat for all you pizza lovers.  The amount of cheese and the flavor of the bread will blow you away!  The salads on the menu are pretty good too.  I really enjoy eating there, and have done so several times. My only complaint would be that they do not take reservations, and the wait can be fairly lone (up to 2 hours on the weekends).  But, if you are a pizza lover, it's probably worth your wait to at least try out this crazy style of pizza.

I do not understand all these raving reviews. That is most likely due to the fact that I didn't eat here because I GOT SO PISSED I COULDN'T GET PAST THE HOST. My sister's boyfriend works here, so I and my group of 6 had plenty of reason to go and love it. I call to make a reso, and the guy says, "No Reservations. You will wait 1.5 hours." and hung up on me! Whatevs. I go anyway to start waiting while my amigos show up. I get there and I couldn't even walk to the "host stand." There had to be 100 people waiting and they are all crazy. I finally get up there and the "host" FINALLY comes up to me and I repeat my story. He shouts, "NO NAMES! ONLY FACES!"  Bitch, please. I was a host for 5 years and there is no way that is an efficient system. (I found out later he keeps a "list" of "descriptions" in the kitchen.) He says its an hour and half and no, we can't sit in my sister's boyfriend's section because he has booths. I try and say he cleared it earlier that day with a manager, but got cut off. I asked to speak to the boyfriend, got a mean look and a huff, and was never talked to again. So I left.   And I will not be going back.

there was a lot of hype about this place, but i'm giving it only 3 stars because neither the pizza, pot pies, or the grinders were all that great. what i can say is that i brought my SoCal friends here for a bit of history and chicago pizza.  it was drizzling outside and the manager let us in 45 minutes before they opened, which was quite cool.  we were already inside as the cooks and wait staff were arriving.  he got behind the bar & served us up some pints & drinks (one of which he had to look up the ingredients to, so A for effort).  we had a mini photo session with the deep, dark wooden furniture and giant menus as a backdrop. it took FOREVER to get our food, i mean i was practically gnawing on my arm by the time it came out.  our waitress was...okay.  not good, not bad, but nothing i'd overtip for. guess if i wasn't here with my friends, i would have been more disappointed.  we did have a lot of laughs.  i took them out for real deep dish the next day.

as an established pizza enthusiast, i must say that i f'n love this place.  whenever i have friends in from out of town, it's usually on my list of dining spots to take them.  the atmosphere is warm and inviting and has a classic Chicago feel to it (no doubt due to the history in and around the building itself).   the mediterranean bread as a starter, the mushroom cap on its head pizza, and a bottle of wine and you are good to go! remember that the wait is all a part of it.  don't come here if you are starving or in a rush.  after you've established your presence for a good half hour or so, just give the elusive host a knowing look and he'll seat you right away.

Yummy in my tummy! I never pass up an opportunity to go here or to send my guests here. The only bad thing can be the wait. I like to say...If you do something well, stick to it! That's what they do here. There are not many options (if that's what you're looking for), but what they do, they do well. I love the meat pizza bowl. CHEESE, CHEESE, GOOEY CHEESE! I can't get enough. My second favorite is the Med flat bread. It is huge and I love all of the spices! A nice way to round it out is to add a salad. Again, the salad is huge! It will easily feed two people. Mixing the two dressing makes for a tangy treat!! Enjoy the nice, simple selection of beers on hand at the bar. Finally roll out of the restaurant if you can fit through the door and hop a cab home.

Apparently 1:30 on a Sunday is the PERFECT time to go here, as we did not have to wait at all and there were several booths still open when we sat down. I had seen this place talked about on Food Network, and being new to Chicago I definitely thought it would be someplace fun to try. It was fairly expensive, and they only take cash. Expect to pay between $10-$13 bucks for a pizza pot pie, depending on the size you get. The pot pie was cute and yummy, the whole wheat crust was the best!! However if you really want to get the most for your bucks, I suggest getting a grinder. My husband got an Italian sausage grinder and it had almost the same of everything that was in the pot pie, just bigger balls of sausage as well as a HUGE pile of green peppers on the side. Like seriously, it was a full green pepper chopped into strips and grilled.  It was a fun experience but I can see how it's kind of gimmicky and touristy and it's not really close to where I live at all. I enjoyed it but I probably won't be going back anytime soon.

Romantic Italian Cheese!  That's the best way to describe this place.  I just absolutely adored the atmosphere!  Very romantic, small with low ceilings and warm wood timbered interior, not at all remotely pretencious, just comfy and casual.  Frank Sinatra playing in the background... A great date place!  Not to mention the creepy history behind the place: a look-out during the St. Valentine's Day Massacre!   Lots of praises for the food as well!  The "pizza pot pie" very inventive!  Not to mention incredibly delicious!  Fresh sauce, lots of cheese, wonderful crust, its great.  And make sure to go for a salad as well, it comes with some of the best salad dressings I've had in a while.

great place to go for some pizza in chicago. its not the deep dish you would expect but still so good. its a pizza pot pie. their menu is very limited and their is only three options for the pizza. sauce with or without meat and with or without a big mushroom. they also have huge salads and big sandwiches or grinders. they have this bread covered in herbs and spices called mediterranean bread. and one dessert. all very simple but oh so very good

When you feast your eyes on the pizza, it may not be what you originally expected for ordering a "Chicago Pizza" but good lord will you be happy you did order it. Just to warn you all, the 1/2 pound is a pretty good serving for one person, and the 1 pounder is about the size of your head. You can't chage the ingredients they throw into this pot-pie looking thing, but I can say without a doubt in my mind that this had the BEST ingredients I've ever had in a pizza. I usually despise peppers in pizzas, but with everything mixed together in this, you cherish each and every different taste you will have the privilege of tasting. Think a sheppard's pie-style pizza, that is, the model is a big puffy pocket, kinda like the chef's hats that look like a mushroom cloud. I've never had a pizza like this so I can get away on semantics and still say Gino's is my favorite pizza and not feel guilty, but I could not say enough about this godsend. This is already one of my top 10 favorite foods. One warning, because they are so deservedly popular you will probably wait, and if you are trying to get carry out they might be too busy to take an order, just be patient and call back later. Patience will always be rewarded with the 1st bite you take.

Quite simply one of the gems in Chicagoland. The bartenders are great - not much for personalities, but they know how to make a good drink. The little old man that used to host has moved to the copycat location of this place out in the burbs. The Mediterranian bread owns my soul.  The salads are great. The ovengrinders are amazing - and the pizza is near orgasmic. The rum flavored desert is just as good, although it seems to have changed over the years.

I didn't particularly find this place friendly nor pleasing.  I wasn't too satisfied with the waitress. I found her to be somewhat patronizing: in a subtle disrespectful manner. I wasn't some jock out to score.I wasn't too upbeat with the crowd. I guess in some way, she bought into the stereotype. I think she was trying to be pleasing. Its located in the Lincoln Park community, which tends to be a comfortable neighborhood: diverse. I didn't sense that here at all! As a matter of fact it was like we were under the microscope. I ordered a vegetarian grinder and was so displeased. The only vegetable contained in the grinder were three small mushrooms. No onions, peppers or any other veggies. The sauce was good and so was the cheese, but I wanted vegetable as part of the order. I would suggest they not refer to it as a vegetarian dish. I would never consider inviting any of my friends to this place.....and I will pass the message onward. First by posting my experience their and secondly by encouraging my friends not to go.  The seating was the pits. I was afraid my knees where going to knock my friends off if I didn't seat completely erect. without the ability to move, the entire time, the seating was very uncomfortable.  What makes this place popular is a mystery to me. Not every black man is a thug, criminal suspect, or a danger to society. Some of us are educated, hard working, intelligent, law abiding men who add decency to our American culture. Such a pity. PS: the salad was awful!!!! A wasted experience? Maybe not. I get to tell others not to go. I could have dealt with the ignorant ambiance if the food had been something to 'brag' about. Honestly: I didn't like anything I ate.

First, and foremost, remember to bring cash with you.  If you forget, there should be an ATM across the street. Now for the fun part of the review, remembering the flat bread and pizza.  My favorite meal there is usually made for two. Chef Salad Mediterranean Bread Pizza (switch off between meat and veggie) If you want to try something different, mix the poppyseed and garlic dressing and dip the bread in.  I haven't had a person complain yet.  Tastes really good mixed. The atmosphere can be a bit loud at times, but it's hit or miss.  Don't let it get to you.  It can be quite packed at times and people are willing to wait so if you are looking to eat right away, have a back up plan.  It's first come, first serve, unless it has changed just recently.  Otherwise, don't miss out on this great food! I forgot to mention their Tortoni is awesome!

Yummy, yummy, I love this place. Just ate there last night in fact. Any place that will serve me pizza which is basically a crust bowl full of cheese is ok in my book!  The atmosphere is very charming and would be great for a romantic evening. It's located in the basement of a brick three flat on Clark right across form he St. Valentine's Day Massacre site. It's dimly lit and everything is made out of wood - the walls, the booths, the bar, the tables. Very rustic. It's a unique environment and unless you are lucky enough to be seated in one of the three tables in the front it can feel a little claustrophobic.  I've only ever had 2 things off the menu. First there is the Mediterranean bread. Carb watchers, stay clear! It basically looks like a pizza crust brushed with olive oil and then sprinkled with various herbs. Sounds simple, but you have to try it. So good! Then there are the cute, little bowls of cheesy goodness known as the pizza pot pie. They come in half-pound and pound sizes and with meat sauce or vegetarian. I always get the half-pound vegetarian with whole mushrooms. It's definitely not your typical pizza. It comes in a bowl and they turn it upside down and out pops your pot pie. The sauce is very flavorful and the cheese is extra gooey. Perfect.  The service can be hit or miss. Last night our waiter was very attentive and quick but in the past I have had ones that forgot we existed. Expect a wait. Last night I was there at 9pm on a Monday and I had to wait 15 minutes for a table. I can only imagine what it's like on the weekends. They do have a bar that you can wait at though if there is room. Overall it's a fun experience and something different than your typical pizza.

Fer cryin' out loud, just go already!  Mediterranean bread - check.  Antipasto - check.  Pizza Pot, Pizza Pot, Pizza Pot Piiiiiiiie - check.  It's all good, just go and check it out.   Plus, as others have mentioned here, you can check out the site of the St. Valentine's Day Massacre!  Spoooooooky! A couple of tips: 1.  Bring cash, and plenty of it.  It can get a little pricey.   2.  Arrive early or later - if you arrive right at prime dining time, you will have to wait a while.

who'd a thought a girl not too fond of pizza would give 4 stars to a pizza joint? i've been converted. this place deserves it.  the wait was a bit much. i was a little suprised to see tens of people sitting outside on the steps. but the food and ambiance make up for it. this place is not for the clostrophobic. a must is the mediteranean bread, served on a tiny plate, this flabread over flows. i ate the bread and salad (huge!), enough to fill me. i tried a bite of the cute little pizza pot pie. it tasted like grandma's spaghetti sauce.  i admit i have no grounds to rate the food here entirely, but if everything is as good as the mediteranean bread, i'm giving it two thumbs up!

There's little I can add to the raves already submitted, but I will say this was an excellent place to take my parents, who are unfamiliar with Chicago.  I told them something about gangsters and the St. Valentine's Day Massacre (I'm sure I butchered the story, but still) and they ate it up.  We went three weeks ago and I'm still craving the Mediterranean bread.  Sort of like naan bread with the olive oil and cheese.  Maybe topped with a little crack, judging by the euphoria I felt after the first taste.  Amazing.  The pizza was exceptional and the "house" cabernet went quite well with everything we tried on the menu.  I can't wait to go back.

Maybe I was there on an off day - but I don't plan to visit again. The food was good, but nothing out of the ordinary and definitely not worth standing in line for.   My boyfriend and I got there right when they opened at noon - we were one of the first couple of people in the restaurant, though it immediately filled up.  Considering that we were there before many others, our service was awful.   I think our waitress came to the table 2 times. One time to order and the other time to bring our food.  We had to ask other servers for our drinks/ bill.  I'll give her the benefit of the doubt, maybe she was having a rough day, but I wasn't impressed at all. The pizza receives a ton of hype but I don't exactly know why.  It's baked in a bowl, that's kind of interesting... and the sauce was good... but that's pretty much the extent of it.

Not that impressed!  We waited for 45 minutes on a Monday night for a table of 4.  Beers were $5 (larger pint glasses though) and it was super crowded!  The pizza pot pie was ok...the meat sauce was bland and could use extra flavor. I lived in Chicago for almost 2 years before visiting this place....it's super hyped up and I don't get why.  The concept is neat and I love the history of the building and site but the food just didn't impress me (especially for the price).  The service was average, I felt like our server didn't feel the need to work very hard, since there was a line out of the door of customers. The PLUS: the Mediterranean Bread  was really good, especially the seasonings.  I was impressed that they offer white or wheat dough. I may go back with some out of town friends, but I didn't feel it's really worth the wait.

Where do I start?  Should I write about the delicious pizza pot pies?  The amazing Mediterranean bread?  The fantastic salad dressings? This restaurant is great.  I went here for a friend's going away dinner, and while we had to wait for about half an hour, the food was well worth it.  You'll leave the restaurant feeling stuffed and satisfied.

So I'm not a fan of pizza. and I'm not a fan of long waiting lines.  But I love this place!!! They won't take reservations, won't even write down your name just remember your face in order, you'll wait a minimum 1 hour, they won't take a credit card - so carry cash!!! But you won't regret any bit of this place!!! Very cute ambiance, awesome food and will turn you into a fan if you are a patient person! The Mediterranean Bread - don't miss that!! And of course, you're there to eat a Pizza Pie!!!  And great for vegetarians too!

I can't tell you what it is about this place that is soo satisfying.  Pizza Pot Pie - can be left to the imagination, because if you describe it , it just sounds like a calzone. - No this is different. The ingredients make this extremely satisfying - hitting the spot in only a way your pseudo Italian grandmother could.  their salads are great. The booths give it a historic feel.

Definitely nothing special!  THE BAD: Long wait (at freaking 10 PM), cramped space, cash only THE GOOD: cozy atmosphere, kind of historical if you get off on that sort of thing The food was just OK. A strong OK. I had the pizza pot pie. Would have liked to try the Famous bread, but no dice.. they didn't bring it. Pizza pot pie is strange.. .like a soupy italian thing in a bread bowl. I would eat it again, but would never fight the hour wait to eat it again... just not THAT good. Everyone should try it once, but once is probably enough for most ppl.

a chicago must i agree.  the pizza put pie was okay but the atmosphere was really cool so I enjoyed it. the hostess man was hilarious.  when i walked iin at 10 pm on a sat it was packed and i stood at the front and he pointed at me and said 45 min.  didnt ask how many or what my name was or anything.  just "45 min, stay here" so i went over to the bar and made my way to the front after 45 min, he then promptly told me to go back to the bar and he would find me when he was ready.  so he came over 5 mins later or so and brought us to the table.  our waiter was very nice and told us the whole story of al capone, very cool.  we got the pizza pot pie bc it is a must, it was okay but im not a sausage fan so that could be a part of it. great atmosphere, i would go again and try the anitpasta, it looked good- and CASH ONLY, dont forget

How sad I am that I never ate here while I actually lived in Chicago. I recently took some friends here while visiting the city because my boyfriend saw it on the Top 10 Pizzas list on the Travel Channel. I am fascinated that the host refuses to take names and still manages to seat people in order. We were told it would be about 40 minutes and I am pretty sure we sat down in less than 30 minutes. PLEASE- keep in mind they only take cash... so, be prepared. The Greek Salad was good and enough for 4 of us to share. The Mediterranean bread is a must. As far as the pizza pot pie goes, I am not sharing with anyone! You can get it with meat or vegetarian. If you opt for meat, they give you the option to forgo the 4 whole mushrooms they place inside. (I hate mushrooms.)  You must check this place out. Oh, and as you walk out the door and across the street to the right, you will see a grassy area and parking lot. That is the sight of the St. Valentine's Day massacre. Rumor has it the building the Chicago Pizza and Oven Grinder Company is housed in was used as a lookout for the shooters.

I few months ago I stumbled on a Travel Channel program showing what their 10 best pizza places in the country are.  The Chicago Pizza & Oven Grinder was one them.  Now I've been to Chicago three times before seeing this show and never heard a thing about these Pizza Pot Pies... so on my  4th trip to the Windy City during the week of July 4th, I made it a point to head out and try this unique pie! Got there around 7pm on Thursday July 5th and was told by the man in the blue shirt that there was a 40 minute wait for my party of four.  Although I expected a wait, I didn't expect the host to remember our name and where to find us... and trust me, I had my doubts... but a mere 20 minutes of sitting at the bar, he found us to take us to our table!   From then, service was very prompt and friendly.  We ordered a small Greek salad and Mediterranean Bread and four half pound Pizza Pot Pies! The salad was fantastic and served four perfectly!  But WOW, the Mediterranean Bread is soooooooo good! Draping way over the plate, the table acts more as a holder than the plate itself!  Soo soft and warm, perfectly covered with various Mediterranean herbs.  I can't imagine anybody not ordering a bread for the table. Then our pot pies arrived!  I personally enjoyed the presentation... they come on a tray looking like mushroom caps, then spooned out of the bowl to your plate in one quick movement.  I'm not a fan of mushrooms and ordered mine without the four huge shrooms.  I was expecting this pie to be greasy, but it wasn't at all!  The crust was a good thickness and chewy, no flakiness at all.  Sauce was very tasty!  From here on out, all my visits to Chicago will include a meal at the Chicago Pizza & Oven Grinder!  Oh Chicago how I love thee!
OMG ... this is no ordinary pizza. It's really a pizza pot pie. And so well worth the wait. The salads are amazing and a meal within themselves.

Pizza pot pies! Yummy. The boy and his friends have dubbed them "pizza bombs" and I have been hearing about them for-e-ver and finally got to try this place the other day. I thought they were really tasty, worthy of the name "pizza bombs," fun & unique & fun & worth doing at least once. ALSO, I appreciate the fact that their wheat dough is tastier than their white dough, and that their mushrooms are fresh and GINORMOUS. ALSO, ditto what everyone has said about the Mediterranean bread, DELISH! The wheat bread version of that is also very good. Even the water was good & lemony.  Oh, but they charge you for every individual glass of soda you order. I don't drink soda, but the bf does, and that is just ridiculous... who still does that nowadays?? They only take cash, BUT, they bring you little pieces of chocolate-covered honeycomb with the check. Awesome!

We went here for dinner last night with two other couples, and all I can say is, "Meh."  Yea, I said it.  "M-E-H."   The food was fine, but a little different.  I could see having one of these weird pizza bread bowls every once in a while, but it's nothing that I need to go out of my way to find.  The bread was great - but it's way too salty. My main problem with this place are the insane rules and regulations they place on diners.  It's kind of like the soup nazi episode on Seinfeld. I mean, come on.  It's a business and if your customers are asking for something, I would oblige.  Two main points. 1)The bread.  I alluded above that the bread is salty.  It is.  It's the perfect sort of appetizer that would be complemented by a side of marinara sauce for dipping.  Being an Italian restaurant, the place obviously has some extra laying around.  Hell, even charge me $1 extra for it.  Somehow - we were told that it's "against the rules" and they won't give it out.  Our waiter was actually very apologetic and said he wishes they could - but it's not allowed.  No explanation.  No logical reasons.  They just won't give it to you.  The bread needs it.  The bread is meant for it!  Just a pointless rule.  It's not charming, it's just dumb. 2) Cash only.  I knew this going in and made a special trip to the ATM, but I pay cash for vending machines, parking meters and cabs (when I'm forced because the cab driver is breaking the law by not accepting credit cards - another rant for another post.)  In 2007 an establishment in the third largest city in America (especially somewhere that is going to have at minimum a $30 tab for two people) should take credit cards.  If this was a third world country or dealt in amounts of $3 and under, I could see the cash only policy.  It just is something I prefer not to deal with. I'm glad I at least got to experience this place firsthand, and there wasn't a wait for our table.  If I would have experienced a long wait for this place, I would have been upset.   Sorry for the long, ranting review.

okay.  its a pizza place and i have to say that the pizza is HORRIBLE here.  but the reason why i have to give at least four stars is because of the salad and the mediterranean bread.  okay, the salad dressing here is AMAZING.  i could seriously drink it!  i'm not a big salad person but i always make sure i order the salad here.  and with every visit here, i make sure to purchase bottles of the sweet and sour poppyseed dressing to take home with me!  the mediterranean bread is also a must.  it is to die for~!  if you're a chicagoan, you have to at least give this place a try.  and remember...  salad and mediterranean bread!

I can't say that I'm impressed, at all.  We got in a little early before the evening rush and were seated right away. The place started to pick up a LOT after that so my suggestion is to come in a bit early, around 6, unless you like standing around and watching other people eat. The Mediterranean bread is ok but really to me it tasted like a saltine with a lot of stuff on top, and a little too salty for my tastes. It was ok but I'm not doing cartwheels about it. I wish there was some marinara sauce for dipping. I got a vegetarian pizza pot pie. The pot pies SOUND like a good idea but to me, it's basically pizza soup in a crust bowl. I was hoping for more veggies and not just the regular sauce sans meat. The cheese is good and I love big honkin' mushrooms, but I would've preferred them sliced. Service was ok enough, no real complaints there. I guess I may be super picky about pizza but this place is more gimmick than anything to me. Just my opinion! It's a nice place so I'd say give it a try if you're curious.

CPOG is a unique little Chicago pizza joint up in the Lincoln Park neighborhood. If you haven't tried it, you should at least go once to try it! CPOG offers great salads, pizza pot pies, sandwiches ("oven grinders"), and the unique mediterranean bread. A party of two that is very hungry could easily share a salad, bread, and two half pound pizza pot pies.  The ambiance is retro. You will hear Frank Sinatra while you are enjoying your meal in a dark formerly garden-style apartment and enjoy the lovely little carnations at your table.  The back of your menu will go over the history of the building, how it is right across from the garage where the infamous Valentine's Day Massacre occurred. That the CPOG might have been a lookout on that horrible day. Some things to note: it's CASH ONLY! The wait will be long, no matter when you go. And finally... parking is difficult in this area.  It is something to try at least once in your life!

YUMMY!!  Start off with the awesome meditteranean bread.  Next get a salad and MIX the house and creamy dressing, so good!  Then get a pizza pot pie.  The "crust" and sauce are so yummy, you'll be full and will continue to finish!  Just one tip, its cash only AND dont go on the weekends where there is a 2 hour wait.

What is all the hype about?  I have been wanted to try th pizza for quite some time, and perhaps I was a little too excited.  The Mediterranean bread is amazing...definitely worth the trip and perhaps worth a trip back.  The pizza was really quite a disappointment.  I was different and good, in it's own way, but it's not something that I'll crave or even want to have again.   I would definitely try the sandwiches or salad on a return trip, if there ever is one.

Go - JUST GO There are about 8 items on the menu- I would say they are all good but i've only had 3 of them...The flat bread, the salad, and the veggie pot pie with mushroom (mmmm... mushrooms) They have other Items as well and I'm sure they are wonderful, but its one of the few places where I NEVER try anything other than my "regular".   The host dosn't need a pen and paper, even when there are 100 people waiting outside, the waiters are consistant and friendly, the bartenders actually know how to pour drinks (go ahead and ask for one of those drinks your grandparents loved....they know how to make it) although I usually go for the house chianti because it just works... don't forget to bring cash!

3 words: Pizza Pot Pie. Some genius (the original owner) though that either pizza, or pot pies, needed something more, and hit a home run with this. They also have awesome oven grinders, which are Italian loaves filled with meats, cheese, and vegetables, and then baked. In addition they have big, monster sized salads. Nothing here is for one person, it's all so big. And good. Did I mention how good the food is? It is. Service is also great. When looking to pig out on unusual Italian style food, go here.

Everyone outside of Chicago is always talking about this place and how they can't wait to go again and do the following: 1. Give your name to the man at the door and assume he's committed your face to memory. 2. Forget they accept CASH ONLY and go across the street to the bar to withdraw cash. 3.  Come back and order an Adam's Apple at the bar while you wait. 4. Take off your jacket and whatever else you can spare because you are so hot and a little buzzed from the drink. 5. Order a Chef's Salad for the table and be sure to mix the sour cream garlic and sweet and sour poppyseed. 6. Don't decide between a white and whole wheat Mediterranean bread- order both! 7. Skip the Grinders and go for the individual pizzas. 8. DO NOT ORDER the meat sauce.  It's gross and can ruin this whole glorious experience. 9. Pay and enjoy one of the little candies. 10. Wink at the host and let him know you'll be back sooner than later.  Oh wait- he already knew that!

I always feel like I'm in an Alpine Lodge when I eat here... which is cool!  Eating here during peak hours is discouraged as it gets hellishly crowded and an hour wait seems to be pretty standard.  Drinks are pricey yet plentiful. This winter I enjoyed a drink called the "Adam's Apple" here which was like a hot cider drink with loads of boozeahol, raisins and a cinnamon stick. So lovely! But that's not the point... the point is the pizza. It's innovative and very tasty. Not really worth trying to describe just come in and try it for yourself. Oh...but don't get the mushrooms unless you're really a fungus fan. They are literally doorknob size.

Oh yes, not only is this place amazing, but has rich tradition to its surroundings. Across the street was the famous Valentine's Day massacre, and there is a cool story about  it on the front of the menu. Read it when you first sit down, as it makes the experience that much better.  This place is a cozy little retaurant with some great boothes that really bring your group close together, making conversation easy. Deifnitely start with the mediterranean bread and a salad for sharing if you have a group of four or more. This can easily be made into a meal itself though, so save yourself for the pizza.  The personal pizzas are really interesting, made like a pie they are baked in the oven. They have two sizes, small and large, but the servers there have always recommended getting the smaller one, as it probably cooks better than the big one. I always go with the white crust, meat sauce, with mushrooms of course.  The wait is the only drag. It's weird how some guy comes around and just remembers who you are and doesn't write anything down. I'm not sure this is too impressive, and it doesn't seem to work when people try to question him as to whether or not they put their names in before someone else. Come here early and get out early to avoid the rush!

Honestly, I don't know why this place gets so much business.  I went here last summer and the only reason I would go back is to get their mediterranean bread.  The wait was super long and it took about 1 hour to get seated.   The personal pizza was pretty nasty.  And seriously, I am not a picky eater.  The crust was really soft and I don't like that at all.  I don't know, the pizzas are nothing great.  This place is not worth the extremely long wait and I would only go back if I was craving the bread.

I want to like this place a lot more, but I just don't.  The non-meat option of pizza is filled with huge mushrooms, the idea of which sounds good, but the mushrooms are raw, which is just not tasty.  Their flat bread is good, but it's hard to screw up dough with butter and garlic.   The service is alright, and it's pretty inexpensive, but I'm just not feeling it.

I had one of the oven grinders years ago... notice i said one and years ago.  I had the mushroom and something about it was just off.  I remember thinking how nasty the uncooked mushrooms are inside, and this coming from someone that normally love mushrooms.
Good food & Pizza. BTW, There is brick in the bathroom that is original St. Valentines Day massacre.

Despite the long waits and cash-only policy, I thoroughly enjoy CP&OG.  They have yummy Belgian beer--and they know how to pour it!  The booths are cozy like you're in your own private restaurant.  I love the mix & match salads, and the hot "pizza" which looks like a bun.  The simplicity of it all really makes this restaurant.

How do cash-only places still exist? Up until that sour turn at the end of the night, I really enjoyed it here.  We only had to wait about a half an hour for a table of eight, which isn't too bad for a Friday night.  The decor is old-timey and unimaginative, but seemingly appropriate for the quirky prose detailed on the enormous menus.  The Meditteranean Bread, which is "described simply as a creation. An honest product with a presence, a substance, a fragrance, and a taste" was a perfectly spiced garlicky flatbread, which is worth coming for alone.  We were able to split a salad between our entire group - while it was a rather standard iceberg lettuce salad, their unique dressing dressed it up quite well.  The pizza pot pies are fun and different, although the sauce was not particularly memorable.

Oh, how I miss this place.  I used to live right down the street for many years and came here often.  I still remember the perfect meal - the appetizer bread with all the wonderful spices, and the pizza pot pie with the mushrooms washed down with a few pins of beer.  I haven't been in a few years, but it sounds like it's still the same, right down to the guy who doesn't take your name, but remembers you anyway.  They also didn't take credit cards, I wonder if that is still the case.  I need to go back soon!

THIS PLACE IS AWWWEESSSOME and im usually not enthusiastic so that says a lot. The mediteranean bread and salad dressing rocked my world. Though the pot pie is the main stay here i think the med bread is better. next time i go im just getting that and the salad cuz it was that good. Chi pizza and oven grinder deserves 5 stars just for the food but the atmosphere which is warm and cozy and the historical location make it a hands down top of the line 5 star

Apparently this is the least romantic place in the city.   I went here for V-day with some friends and it's the only time when there has been no line.  Zero.  And there were a lot of single people eating alone- I guess they have the inside track and come in droves this one night a year.  Could have to do with the Valentines massacre taking place right across the street?? I used to eat here when I first moved to Chicago right out of college and it was legendary.  The mediterranean bread with fresh herbs and cheese, the over-sized salads with delicious dressings and the pizza-pot-pies that have mushrooms the size of golf balls.  This was THE date place for all of my friends. The lines are too long, the decor hasn't been updated since the gas crisis(the real one in the 70's), and there really are only five menu items(bread, pizza, salad, grinders, and one dessert), but this place is an institution. Sure you can find a better decor, better food, better service, and a better wait.  But you can only find one Chicago Pizza and Oven Grinder.

I went here last week. The place was absolutely packed and there was there was this guy in the front who immediately told us that there was a 35-minute wait and for us to wait by the bar. He didn't take our names or anything like that so I was skeptical from the beginning.  We waited by the door because I didn't want him to forget about us. But, after waiting for what seemed like forever, we finally got our seat.  When you go here, get the bread. It was delicious and you will be seeing it on other tables As far as the pizza goes, I wasn't that impressed. It is a great idea with the whole pot pie scheme goes. But, there was something missing.  The staff was great and the environment was classy. It's worth the visit.

This was a unique food experience.  I liked the Grinders and the restaurant has a charm about it.  It's very casual and low key. I guess it has a cult following, but I heard most of these people are completely harmless.
Love the pizza potpie. It is cooked upside down, with the crust on top, cheese and toppings on the bottom. It looked like a mushroom when the waiter brought it out. Very tasty!

Why is this place so popular?  First, you get to wait outside on an obscure block of scenic Clark Street.   Then you get to eat in a dining room that has the ambiance of a well-lit cave.  And the pizza is nothing special: basically a bread bowl filled with tomato sauce and a thick slab of melted cheese on top.  Sorry to be such a bummer, but this is not my favorite restaurant.

This place gets PACKED. Arrive early with all of your party because they would not seat you otherwise. Everyone's gotta come here at least once for their grinders, its delicious, and I don't usually like my "pizzas" with a lot of bread (I'm not a deep dish fan either). We had their salad, which was fresh and good, and their Mediterranean bread which was also awesome. This is a real Chicago gem.

I lived in Chicago for 3 years and this is the one place I must visit every time I go back.  If you can, go on a week night to lessen the wait time.  This place is tiny.  Don't be alarmed when you tell the host you have a party of 2 or 4 or whatever and he just nods.  He doesn't ask for your name and you wonder how in the world will he know when it's your turn.  But somehow he does and it all works out just fine.  Bring cash because that's all they take. Here's what my husband and I order every time we go to CPOG.  It's the perfect amount of food for sharing. Mediterranean Bread Chopped Salad (Large if we are feeling extra hungry) 1/2 pounder meat pizza The secret is their amazing homemade salad dressing.  Mix the garlic sour cream dressing with the honey poppy seed and it is truly heaven in your mouth.  It's great on the salad of course but also as a dip for the Mediterranean bread.  I can't even describe how good it is.  Your meal is finished by complimentary dark chocolate covered toffee.   This may be my all time favorite restaurant.  You must try it.

I have always thought of this place as a great hidden gem in Chicago.  I must admit I don't actually lean towards pizza, I generally get the veggie grinder.  The pizza is actually more like a pot pie, where it is served in a bowl with a light flaky crust.  So if you are looking for dough with red sauce and cheese on the top, this is not the place for you.  But as for the grinders, they are great.  I have not been able to finish one yet, and got quite peeved when my boyfriend gave away my leftover half of my grinder.  But by far, my favorite thing and what keeps me coming back time and time again is the flat bread.  It is worth the wait. I do have to remind myself every time that they don't take credit cards to prevent the embarrassing scene of having to run down the street to an ATM to get cash.  And if you are a group of more than 4 it is a TIGHT squeeze in the booths.  But a fun time and yummy flat bread.

The good:  neat, intimate space, good sandwiches, on a very walkable stretch of Clark St. The bad:  their strange upside-down pizza is the only pizza they have, their food is quite overpriced, they're cash-only. It's a strange place; if you want actual pizza, don't be fooled.  My Pie is just two blocks north and a much better deal.

The pizza & bread are great, and you won't find any other like it in town (perhaps even country).   But be prepared for some psychological torture as you endure the wait.  Because the host doesn't take names or add people to a list, many people (I swear I'm not the only one!) find themselves unnecessarily stressed out.  "Will he remember me?" "If I'm out in the patio area instead of next to the lecturn do my chances of getting a table diminish?"   "Will I offend the master if I ask him when we'll be seated--and get another 30 minutes tacked onto our wait?"  ---These questions and more will go through your mind as you wait.  The solution:  suck it up and buy a $5.50 Tall glass of Becks--eventually a table will pop up, and once you finally sit down you'll find yourself feeling very grateful to the man who only moments before wielded so much power over your gastronomic destiny.

I just had a random flashback to this spot: HUGE salads and amazing Mediterranean bread (aka flatbread). I know they have grinders and pizza here, but we didn't even attempt to try either after filling up on the unusually large salad (which kept falling off the sides of the plate because it was piled so high) and even larger piece of flatbread. The dressing choices are great as well which we used to dip the flatbread in...

I've been coming here for years. I can remember coming here with my family as a kid. It's really like no other pizza place that I can think of. It's small, dimly lit, dark oak everywhere and people have been known to wait over an hour for a table. They only take cash and no reservations. ......Okay good, you're still reading. When you go, go with at least one friend, come hungry and forget everything you know about the whole Atkins's diet, it useless here. This place is simple, limited beer list, two beers on tap, Miller Lite and Becks both in huge 22 oz glasses. Good simple salads with three dressings, (mix the garlic and the poppy seed, strange but good!). They also have a warm flat bread seasoned with olive oil, Parmesan cheese and oil olive, you rip it up with your hands. Now about their pizza, it comes with either white or wheat bread, mushrooms or none, (and their whole mushrooms!), meat or veggie sauce and 1/2 or a full pound. Yes, that means no large small or large, hence why coming here with a friend and splitting everything is key. Their pizza is more of a pot pie. It comes out like a golden dome of bread, they flip it over and they scoop out the dish and you now have a bowl of bread filled with pizza goodness, including a half inch of cheese. They have these grinders, kinda like Quizno's on steroids. You probably can get two to three meals out of them. I have gone with a friend split everything each had a beer and only needed a $20 each. Service is usually good and friendly, but again it can get really crowded so I recommend going on a Tuesday or Wednesday night around 5:30 or 6 to avoid them. Construction is going on now, but they usually have valet or if you're lucky you can street parking a block or two away. If you love carbs and want a different twist on pizza, trot on over.

This past Friday night in Chicago was a downright miserable one.   The cold rain fell sideways and the wind blew out even the sturdiest of umbrellas.  Miserable commuters made their way through puddled streets onto busses and trains crowded with rain soaked passengers.  Everyone wondered what level of hell they had just entered, as they all just tried to get home. My boyfriend and I found a nice respite from that ugly night at the Chicago Pizza and Oven Grinder.  This was the PERFECT place to escape the Windy City's worst weather.   The place was packed when we walked in, but we managed to find two spots at the cozy bar almost immediately.   We were quoted a 35 minute wait and were seated in about that amount of time.   Two 1/2 pound meat pot pies, one chef's salad and one order of Mediterranean bread later - we were full and drowsy.  I stopped the manager as he was passing by to find out just how he  remembers the order of everyone coming in.  (They do not take names).  He smiled and told me that he's been doing it for ten years and that with enough practice, you just get good at it. Indeed.

I didn't think it was possible to find better pizza than the pizza I've had in Chicago. And then I discovered Chicago Pizza & Oven Grinder. This isn't your typical pizza- personally, I think it's much better! And most pizza places don't have salads this good as well.

My friends have always raved about this place and I had been dying to go. But honestly I do not know what all the hoopla was. I honestly did not care for the upside down pizza. It was ok and this is from someone who loves all pizza. The wait to get seated totally sucks. And the guy who sits you doesn't write down your name. I guess he has been there forever. But I honestly can't believe he actually remembers the order you came in. I think he sat another party before us that came in after us. Not impressed at all, but I might give it another chance but not in the too near future.

meh.  i can't complain about the price (very reasonable) but the menu is limited and the food is only okay.  i will say that the Mediterranean bread (we tried thanks to Yelp - thanks guys!) was awesome.  feta, spices, etc. on a huge flatbread you tear with your fingers.  also got a huge greek salad for the table, for which four iceberg lettuce heads must have given their lives. as I was full by this time i got a chef's salad (also all iceberg - about two heads of it).  i'm a huge salad fan and i like arugula, romaine, whatever - just don't give me all iceberg. Everyone else got the pizza pot pie, which i tried and was definitely not thrilled with.  fiance didn't really like his either.  it's essentially a calzone, which in and of itself is not a bad thing, i just don't think they do theirs very well.  oh and this place is NOT GOOD for groups - it is small and cramped.  good for 2-4 people, max

I went here years ago.  From what I remember, the bread for the "oven grinders" was really, really good.  I didn't try the pizza, well, because I don't like pizza.  I do remember it was like pizza served in a bowl, with the sauce/ingredients in the bowl, with the dough on top, like a pot pie.  I remember that the place is small, and we waited a long time to get seated.

I liked it here many moons ago. The pizza was chock full of veggies and slightly too much tomahto, but the inverted crust had a delish flavour. My favourite part of this place is the history and its cozy, cloak and dagger feel.  Wear a trench coat and fedora on chilly or rainy days.
Cute, cozy environment.  Great sandwiches which proved to last one extra dinner. Good thing I brought cash as they don't take credit cards!

Coming here was kind of like how I felt after my first sexual experience.  That's it?  Wait.   Really?  That's it?  In other words, I fell victim to the hype that surrounds this place.  I was expecting something phenomenal and mind-blowing.  Those lines out on Clark Street, I knew they all must be waiting for something. . .something like orgasmic pizza pot pies made with golden crusts?     I thought the pizza pot pie tasted like average lasagna with crust instead of noodles.  The flat bread was really good, but again, not unbelievable.  The salad?  Good, you can't really mess up lettuce unless it's withered (and it wasn't).  The salad dressing was pretty damn tasty I will give them that.   I HATE the fact that this place only takes cash.  It's not like you don't make enough money - pay the credit card fees already.  This place wasn't BAD (hence the three stars) but it  wasn't amazing.  Still, I am willing to give it another go.  Because maybe just MAYBE like with sex, the more you try it, the better it gets.

We are regulars here.  Nice cozy atmosphere and the service is always good.  We always get the pizza pot pies and the mediterranean style flat bread, and we are never disappointed.  I would highly reccomend CPOG!

The pizza pot pies are decent (very filling) but the real reason to come here, like everyone else has already said.. is the Mediterranean Bread!  So amazing.  The place is small and dark and you almost always have to wait, but its worth it for the experience.  Valet parking is available for $8 too.

It's been a while since I visited CPOG, but the food was memorable.  I enjoyed the bread, but I enjoyed the Pizza Pot Pie even better.  My mouth still waters (yes, even as I type this) when I think about that wonderful meal.  Yes, it is worth the wait, and yes, you will become addicted...

I really liked the idea of an oven grinder when I went here.  We started out with an appetizer that was a big piece of tasty bread.  It was delicious. However, the oven grinder was over-rated.  Everyone talks about how cool it is....but after the wait I wish I hadn't even bothered.  The sauce is way too peppery (as in green pepper) and I really felt like I wasted my time and money. If you really like green pepper, a comfy, dark place and don't mind a long wait...you'll be happy here.

The restaurant is set in the basement of an old historic house. There's a Chicago-gang story related and you can read about it on the menu when you are there!  What's very cool is that the host remembers the entire wait list in his head!!! He'll tell you it is around an hour wait and surely enough, after an hour, he'll come looking for you to sit your party.  What's tasty? EVERYTHING! We started with the large salad and Mediterranean bread. The pizza pot pie was so good! I love the mushrooms in the pizza pot pies. The Grinders are huge, filled with meat and just ridiculously big.  The place is small, there are booths and tables and a bar. It's always bustling with people! A great experience, from waiting till the end of your meal! **CASH ONLY**

Despite the hour+ wait I usually suffer through, once the food arrives it's all worth it.  I've only gotten the pizza because after the first time it was so delicious I couldn't bear to get anything else.  Get the mediterranean bread, too as an appetizer... so delicious.  Good wine selection, too. And while you're waiting for your table, grab a beer at the bar if you can finangle a seat there.  Don't be nervous, either, when the man with the "wait list" has it all in his head... when your table is ready, he will remember you and find you.
I could wax poetic about the Mediterranean Bread and the Pizza Pot Pie.  They're that good.

Get here early if you don't want to wait, the place is pretty small and usually always packed. Also be sure you have cash, they don't take credit cards and there is no ATM in the place.  If you go make sure to get the mediterranean bread it is huge and amazing. The Pizza Pot Pie were neat but not that great. I would recommend an over grinder over the pizza. This is a place you need to go at least once to see what the deal is but its not a place I think about going to often.   If you make it over here be sure to go across the street and check out the site of the St. Valentine's Day Massacre.

I am salivating just thinking about the Mediterranean bread dipped in the mix of salad dressings.  Seriously.  Actual saliva is being produced in my mouth at this very moment.  & I'm not ashamed of that because once you go, you'll understand what I mean.  I get just the salad (which is delish in a fresh kinda way) & the Mediterranean bread & am stuffed.  No kidding.  & the Mediterranean bread is tasty the second day around, too, if you can't finish it all in one sitting.  Mix the dressings ... you've heard that before, but it's worth repeating.  I only give it 4 out of 5 stars cuz I've had the Pizza Pot Pie & was EH about it.  Otherwise, our waitress was wry & I like that ... a waitress with a sense of humor.  Good stuff here, folks, & don't forget to read the back of the menu to find out the history of the neighborhood. Ed. Note:  YOU CAN GET A BOTTLE OF THE DRESSING!!!  SWEET GOOGLY MOOGLY!!!

Worth the wait everytime.  Make sure you get the house salad with both dressings.  Perfect place to go with friends, grab a beer and wait.  And don't worry about them not taking names, they'll definitely remember you.

My high school boyfriend intro'd me to this restaurant back in 1995 and I've been in love ever since. I've told so many people about this place over the years and its always so good. It is worth the wait and the pizza pot pie is YUM, the mediteranean bread is not to be missed!

Back when this place first opened, I remember this place being the bomb!!  It was chic, and fresh, and there were no other places like it.  Tonite, I took my hub expecting the same experience.  I wasn't completely disappointed.  The place looked exactly the same as it did back way when.  And the Mediterranean bread was to die for, as usual.  But I wasn't impressed with our salad or our pizza.  I was reviewing the menu and noted at the beginning of the left side where the salads where about how the salad makers put alot of thought and were creative, blah, blah, blah.  I tell you now...anyone who can cut up iceberg lettuce and break it up, slice up a few onions, cut tomato wedges and slices of cucumber, add the olives, cheese and artichokes is a genius, according to this place.  C'mon people...this isn't even the good kind of lettuce.  Add some green that actually has some nutritional value!!  I will give props to the fact that it is a huge salad, and consideration should be given to serving it in a salad bowl (when my hub served the salad, the olives were at the edge.  They fell off the plate and rolled onto the floor...so much for the olives.  I did get some replacements).  The pizza itself was disappointing.  I could have sworn that we ordered sausage and mushroom, but all we got were these two huge mushrooms (one shroom in each half).  It was a half of a half, but still...only one shroom and no sausage in sight.  But we must have been hungry because we did finish the pizza.  Having said all the negative, they did have a sour cream garlic dressing that was pretty delicious.  Use it to dip the bread in.  The Mediterranean bread is a must to anyone who goes here.  It was the most fulfilling part of the dinner.  And, after everything is eaten and done, we were full.  As I type this, I'm still feeling the stuffy effects of food in the tum.  We didn't get to try the wine because one thing I did forget is that this place takes CASH ONLY.  Not being the type to lug all that much cash around, we were limited to how much we could order.  But it turned out to be the appropriate thing anyway.  Would I go here again?  Yes, but just for the Mediterranean bread, unless someone can tell me where to find it elsewhere and with other better selections.  And their wine selection looked decent, so some bread, some wine...hell, I might as well call this church!!
The pizza pot pies are amazing, even if you have to wait 2 hours to get them.  Besides, the Clark Bar is right across the street. Go hang out for a while, you'll be all right.

I just ate here for the first time and can't believe I"ve been missing out on it for all these years!  They have these pizza pot pies that are delicious and very unique.  The atmosphere is cool, feels like a ski town kind of place. The salad is great  (and I'm not even a salad person) and they give you three dressings with it.

I go here just for the Mediterranean Bread and the salads because the pizza is just too much on top of that. I don't know what they put in that bread, but it is so addicting.  I want some right now just thinking about it!

Tried this pizza place for the first time tonight and I loved it!  It's a very small restaurant so be prepared to wait...we just sat at the bar and had a few drinks and were seated within 30 minutes. Once we sat down the service was very fast. We had a small salad (more than enough for 2 people) to start with the Mediterranean bread. I can't remember the last time I had something as good as the Mediterranean bread. I was pretty full after that, but couldn't resist the veggie pot pie.  It was a bit on the cheesy side for me, but others may not mind that. My friend got the meatball pizza, which he was a huge fan of.  There are so many fantastic pizza places to try in Chicago, but everyone should add Chicago Pizza & Oven Grinder to their list!

This place may be my new favorite.  I went Saturday afternoon around 2 and there was no wait.  I usually avoid this place because of the long line, but I think I found the perfect time to go.  We just got the mediterannean bread, which is fantastic, and salad, and there was enough leftover for a whole other person.  The food is great and the portions are huge.  I'll have to try the pizza next time, but I'm very satisified with the bread and salad!  It was all delicious!

If you want to get into this place, try going on during the week.  The salad is great, and so is the pizza. Its very unique but delicious!! I haven't tasted the oven grinders because I always get pizza, but have heard great things.

The long lines to get inside the restaurant may be discouraging, but it is definitely worth it.  The pizza pot pie is worth waiting for and the only thing I'd get there.  The half pounder is more than enough and the full pound pot pie is ridiculously large but so delicious!

It's appropriate that this place is located across the street from the site of the St. Valentine's Day Massacre, because the pizza pot pie for which it's famous is a killer. Paired with one of the generously-sized salads, it makes for a very filling meal. Don't let the usually long lines deter you . . . this is definitely worth the wait.
People wait outside this place all the time, but I don't see what the big deal is.  The pizza pot pie is not that good, but the vegetarian sandwich is quite delicious.  Overall, not worth the wait!

Super cute place. Very authentic Italian feeling. There is ALWAYS a wait here, so plan to stay for a while. When you walk in, don't be confused that there is not a hostess. They only take "names" by remembering your face. The food is excellent. The pizza is good and the sandwiches are amazing, but HUGE!

The Pizza Pot Pie is the star of the show here, the name pretty accurately describes what you'll be getting - it's cooked in a bowl, then scooped out hot to your plate, the end result is like a bread bowl with an italian-style sauce/stew inside, topped with a big wad of molten cheese.  Delicious!!! Some folks rave about the oven grinders, but I've never tried one.  If you don't think that the pizza pot pie will fill you up, try the tasty Mediterranean Bread as an appetizer.  Be prepared for a wait to get seated, CPOG has never taken reservations.
Great grinders and pizza here! I went once and want to go back again. They have a great menu with tastey salads, pizza and more.  The line to get in is almost always long but it is totally worth it!

I almost want to tell you not to go cause you'll become addicted. Either that or you'll hate it. But how could you when the thick accented host  sizes you up and gives you an estimate for a table without asking your name? Its magic. Salad + dressings + med bread = ecstasy. The actual pizza won't change your life, but everything else will. Go.

This place serves what has been described a Pizza Pot Pie that is best described as "pizza in a bowl" (or a "cup" for a smaller portion). You get the ingredients of a pizza like a crust, cheese, meat, and then the bowl is inverted so then you dig in. After wiping the smirk off your face, you will enjoy this dish. Maybe calling it pizza is a stretch, but it's close enough. The oven grinders are sandwiches, but have not had them.
You have to go here with more than 2 people so you can get both a pizza and an oven grinder!  the wait here is super long but its totally worth it!
